articles.headline: With Europe-Canada Deal Near Collapse, Globalization’s Latest Chapter Is History
articles.snippet: As the agreement effectively died, it underscored the extent to which trade has become politically radioactive around much of the globe.
articles.abstract: As the agreement effectively died, it underscored the extent to which trade has become politically radioactive around much of the globe.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Even in this moment of fierce reassessment of the merits of free trade, the deal promoting commerce between the European Union and Canada seemed like a safe bet to secure political blessing on both sides of the Atlantic.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and James Kanter

articles.headline: AT&T Aims for an Empire in Merger Talks With Time Warner
articles.snippet: A deal would give the giant TV distributor and internet provider a collection of programming like HBO and movies like “Suicide Squad.”
articles.abstract: A deal would give the giant TV distributor and internet provider a collection of programming like HBO and movies like “Suicide Squad.”
articles.lead_paragraph: For companies that sell consumers cable and internet service, merely distributing entertainment and programs is not enough. They want to own them.
articles.byline: By Leslie Picker, Andrew Ross Sorkin and Emily Steel

articles.headline: Think Your Retirement Plan Is Bad? Talk to a Teacher
articles.snippet: Schoolteachers and others who pursue careers of service in exchange for modest paychecks get lightly regulated retirement plans that often charge excessive fees.
articles.abstract: Schoolteachers and others who pursue careers of service in exchange for modest paychecks get lightly regulated retirement plans that often charge excessive fees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Margaret Jusinski first got to know her investment broker through the breakfasts he provided when he visited her public school in the leafy suburbs of New Jersey, where she teaches middle-school children computer coding and how to build robots made of Legos.
articles.byline: By Tara Siegel Bernard

articles.headline: Airbnb Sues Over New Law Regulating New York Rentals
articles.snippet: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has signed a bill that will impose fines up to $7,500 on hosts who rent out housing for fewer than 30 days.
articles.abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has signed a bill that will impose fines up to $7,500 on hosts who rent out housing for fewer than 30 days.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hours after Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York signed a bill that would impose steep fines on Airbnb hosts who break local housing regulations, Airbnb filed a federal lawsuit contending the new law would cause it “irreparable harm.”
articles.byline: By Katie Benner

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Makes Pitch for Mandate and a Swing-State Sweep
articles.snippet: Hoping to sweep swing states, Hillary Clinton spent the day in Ohio. In North Carolina, Donald Trump was restrained, predicting victory but saying that no matter the results he “will be happy with myself.”
articles.abstract: Hoping to sweep swing states, Hillary Clinton spent the day in Ohio. In North Carolina, Donald Trump was restrained, predicting victory but saying that no matter the results he “will be happy with myself.”
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Hillary Clinton entered the final phase of her campaign on Friday, working to ensure a victory that is decisive enough to earn a mandate for her presidency and a surge of voters to help Democrats win congressional races.
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: A Constellation of Influencers: Behind the Curtain at Teneo
articles.snippet: How an advisory firm with roots in the Democratic Party establishment fosters a network of power and politics for the benefit of its clients.
articles.abstract: How an advisory firm with roots in the Democratic Party establishment fosters a network of power and politics for the benefit of its clients.
articles.lead_paragraph: Whether participating in glittery dinners with heads of state, or tête-à-têtes in the Oval Office, Andrew Liveris, the chief executive of Dow Chemical, has regularly visited the White House.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and J. David Goodman

articles.headline: Outside Money Favors Hillary Clinton at a 2-to-1 Rate Over Donald Trump
articles.snippet: Organizations supporting Mrs. Clinton have raised nearly $200 million, defying expectations that conservatives and corporations would dominate spending.
articles.abstract: Organizations supporting Mrs. Clinton have raised nearly $200 million, defying expectations that conservatives and corporations would dominate spending.
articles.lead_paragraph: Six years after a Supreme Court decision opened vast new channels for money to flow into national elections, Democrats have built the largest and best-coordinated apparatus of outside groups operating in the 2016 presidential campaign, defying expectations that conservative and corporate wealth would dominate the race.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Rachel Shorey

articles.headline: AT&T Agrees to Buy Time Warner for $85.4 Billion
articles.snippet: The potential union would probably face heavy scrutiny from government regulators.
articles.abstract: The potential union would probably face heavy scrutiny from government regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the world of media, bigger remains better.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: A Democrat Deft With a Firearm Tightens the Race for the Senate
articles.snippet: Jason Kander, an ex-military officer, released a TV ad in which he assembled an AR-15 blindfolded. Suddenly, his race against Senator Roy D. Blunt was close.
articles.abstract: Jason Kander, an ex-military officer, released a TV ad in which he assembled an AR-15 blindfolded. Suddenly, his race against Senator Roy D. Blunt was close.
articles.lead_paragraph: O’FALLON, Mo. — For much of the year, Democrats viewed Jason Kander as a perfect Senate candidate running in the wrong state.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer

articles.headline: A New Era of Internet Attacks Powered by Everyday Devices
articles.snippet: The attack on the web’s infrastructure laid bare new vulnerabilities linked to our reliance on cameras, smart thermostats and the rest of the internet of things.
articles.abstract: The attack on the web’s infrastructure laid bare new vulnerabilities linked to our reliance on cameras, smart thermostats and the rest of the internet of things.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When surveillance cameras began popping up in the 1970s and ’80s, they were welcomed as a crime-fighting tool, then as a way to monitor traffic congestion, factory floors and even baby cribs. Later, they were adopted for darker purposes, as authoritarian governments like China’s used them to prevent challenges to power by keeping tabs on protesters and dissidents.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth

articles.headline: Regulatory Microscope Lies Ahead for AT&T and Time Warner
articles.snippet: The deal will probably face a much sterner regulatory review than the Comcast-NBC Universal merger in 2009.
articles.abstract: The deal will probably face a much sterner regulatory review than the Comcast-NBC Universal merger in 2009.
articles.lead_paragraph: A cable and internet provider decides to buy an entertainment conglomerate.
articles.byline: By Leslie Picker and Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: Obama Assists 150 State Candidates, Targeting G.O.P.’s Grip on Legislatures
articles.snippet: Republicans control most statehouse chambers, but with Donald J. Trump stumbling, Democrats hope for down-ballot gains in Minnesota, Colorado, Nevada and elsewhere.
articles.abstract: Republicans control most statehouse chambers, but with Donald J. Trump stumbling, Democrats hope for down-ballot gains in Minnesota, Colorado, Nevada and elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: FARIBAULT, Minn. — For half a dozen years, Republicans have swept into statehouses across the nation, winning more legislative chambers than at any time in history and pushing states to the right on issues such as abortion, voting rights, labor unions and gender identity.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Presses Her Advantage Over a Struggling Donald Trump
articles.snippet: With a strong lead in national polls, Mrs. Clinton is urging core Democratic constituencies to vote early in states where balloting has begun.
articles.abstract: With a strong lead in national polls, Mrs. Clinton is urging core Democratic constituencies to vote early in states where balloting has begun.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton moved aggressively on Sunday to press her advantage in the presidential race, urging black voters in North Carolina to vote early and punish Republican officeholders for supporting Donald J. Trump, even as Mr. Trump’s party increasingly concedes he is unlikely to recover in the polls.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: Turkey’s Push to Join Battle for Mosul Inflames Tension With Iraq
articles.snippet: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s insistence on a direct role, citing a “historical responsibility” that Iraq rejects, is undermining American goals in the region.
articles.abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s insistence on a direct role, citing a “historical responsibility” that Iraq rejects, is undermining American goals in the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq — A dispute between Iraq and Turkey has emerged as a dramatic geopolitical sideshow to the complicated military campaign to retake Mosul, Iraq’s second-largest city, from the Islamic State.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Now at GQ, Keith Olbermann Takes His Outrage Online
articles.snippet: Mr. Olbermann, the itinerant sports and news broadcaster, is making a series of commentaries opposing Donald J. Trump.
articles.abstract: Mr. Olbermann, the itinerant sports and news broadcaster, is making a series of commentaries opposing Donald J. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: Keith Olbermann knows the question before it is asked: How, after a career spent anchoring news and sports shows on ESPN, MSNBC, NBC and Fox, has he come to be delivering anti-Donald J. Trump commentaries on GQ magazine’s website?
articles.byline: By Richard Sandomir

articles.headline: WikiLeaks’ Gift to American Democracy
articles.snippet: Revelations about Donald Trump and the Clinton campaign have pulled back the curtain on the political-celebrity mythmaking the media too often abets.
articles.abstract: Revelations about Donald Trump and the Clinton campaign have pulled back the curtain on the political-celebrity mythmaking the media too often abets.
articles.lead_paragraph: You sure have to hand it to the Russians.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Time Warner’s Non-Mogul Mogul Who Foretold Its Worth
articles.snippet: Jeffrey L. Bewkes, the telecom giant’s chief executive, stuck to his guns over the years, confident that his company would get the deal it deserved.
articles.abstract: Jeffrey L. Bewkes, the telecom giant’s chief executive, stuck to his guns over the years, confident that his company would get the deal it deserved.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeffrey L. Bewkes, the chief executive of Time Warner, made a big bet in the summer of 2014 when he rejected an $80 billion takeover bid by 21st Century Fox, controlled by Rupert Murdoch.
articles.byline: By Emily Steel

articles.headline: Making Sense of AT&T’s Bid for Time Warner
articles.snippet: The proposed $85 billion merger faces tough regulatory scrutiny, but the potential to challenge cable companies may make a compelling case.
articles.abstract: The proposed $85 billion merger faces tough regulatory scrutiny, but the potential to challenge cable companies may make a compelling case.
articles.lead_paragraph: “You had a lot of people saying you should’ve combined a donkey with a rabbit and gotten a flying unicorn.”
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Swift Opposition to Resurrection of AT&T Giant
articles.snippet: Much of the concern about AT&T’s $85.4 billion purchase of Time Warner is rooted in how consumers have fared since Comcast bought NBCUniversal.
articles.abstract: Much of the concern about AT&T’s $85.4 billion purchase of Time Warner is rooted in how consumers have fared since Comcast bought NBCUniversal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over three decades ago, such was AT&T’s monopoly over the nation’s communications networks that the government forcefully shattered its empire.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Election May Be a Turning Point for Legal Marijuana
articles.snippet: Opinion polls point to the possibility that voters in California and four other states will legalize marijuana in what some call a vast experiment in public health.
articles.abstract: Opinion polls point to the possibility that voters in California and four other states will legalize marijuana in what some call a vast experiment in public health.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — To the red-and-blue map of American politics, it may be time to add green. The movement to legalize marijuana, the country’s most popular illicit drug, will take a giant leap on Election Day if California and four other states vote to allow recreational cannabis, as polls suggest they may.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller
